item.title: Uncertainty and creativity make good company
item.description:
Uncertainty and creativity make good company

Certainty sounds like something rock solid and immovable - something upon which you can depend. In reality it's ephemeral. Yet human beings love the idea of certainty and when we're thrust into situations of change and uncertainty, it feels like a test. Sometimes it even feels like punishment.

item.title: Futurists say this is what offices will look like in 2030
item.description:
Futurists say this is what offices will look like in 2030

Watch "Mad Men" or take a look at old photos of offices of decades past and what do you notice? Things don't look all that different. Sure the gender ratio has ( hopefully!) improved, the typewriters have been replaced by computers, and open areas are no longer just for secretaries, but the basics remain the same - desks, chairs, a lunch room, conference tables and chairs, etc.

item.title: Can agile scale and does it matter?
item.description:
Can agile scale and does it matter?

Five years ago, when I visited Zappos, CEO Tony Hseih pointed out that as organizations grow they become less effective. Each person you add increases productivity by a little less than the previous employee. Eventually, a large organization takes man-years to do what a small one could do in man-weeks.

item.title: Webinar Q&A: Answers On How To Validate Business Ideas
item.description:
Webinar Q&A: Answers On How To Validate Business Ideas

Strategyzer co-founder Alex Osterwalder responds to audience questions posed during our free webinar session on How To Validate Business Ideas.

item.title: We Are Failing At Failing
item.description:
We Are Failing At Failing

We don't fail enough; we need to fail faster, fail bigger, fail more often; convince our leaders that failure is acceptable. It's almost as if we are saying that: "if only we were more accomplished failers, we could create miracles!" I hear such calls every day in conversations with corporate [...]

item.title: How is lean different from Taylorism?
item.description:
How is lean different from Taylorism?

In a special column, Michael Ball√© breaks from his standard practice of answering readers' questions to weigh in on the controversy comparing lean management to "Taylorism" triggered by the recent story " Medical Taylorism" in the New England Of Medicine. -Ed. How is lean different from Taylorism? They are completely different indeed.

item.title: Do You Have a 'Touchpoint Plan'?
item.description:
Do You Have a 'Touchpoint Plan'?

Join us live at Entrepreneur's Accelerate Your Business event series in Chicago or Denver. Secure your spot " Have you ever thought through your business from your customer's perspective? I love that moment in , when Anne Hathaway's character opens an order -- the way a customer would -- from her own company, to see how things look.

item.title: The Biology of Corporate Survival
item.description:
The Biology of Corporate Survival

Corporate mortality is on the rise, driven by the dynamism and complexity of the business environment. This article, first published in Harvard Business Review, describes six principles that confer robustness in complex systems, such as tropical forests, stock markets, and even companies. Understanding these principles can mean the difference between survival and extinction.

item.title: 4 Simple Tricks to Avoid Merge Conflicts - The Team Coder
item.description:
4 Simple Tricks to Avoid Merge Conflicts - The Team Coder

Git is a great tool if you have multiple developers working on the same code base. However, there is one thing which can be very annoying if your team uses Git: Merge conflicts! Two developers have changed the same part of the code and then Git doesn't know what to do.

item.title: Design As Strategy: How Design Can Improve Your Business Outcomes | Game-Changer
item.description:
Design As Strategy: How Design Can Improve Your Business Outcomes | Game-Changer

Design thinking. is it a methodology, mindset, trend, the new must in business acumen, or all of the above? Regardless of your interpretation, it has been around for quite a while. The bottom-line is most leaders still don't understand how exactly it helps improve or drive new business outcomes. Why?
